div.style: font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 9px; text-align: justify; line-height: 1.4; color: #333;

foreignObject.div: This study examined the effects of CRISPR-induced knockouts of algaenan biosynthesis genes (PRX and COPOX) in Nannochloropsis oceanica. Despite contamination issues with wild-type strains, the project provided insights into gene function and algaenan formation.

div.style: font-family: Arial, sans-serif; font-size: 9px; text-align: justify; line-height: 1.4; color: #333;

foreignObject.div: Nannochloropsis oceanica is a marine microalga with significant potential for biofuel production due to its high lipid content. The cell wall of N. oceanica contains algaenan, a biopolymer that contributes to its recalcitrance to extraction processes. This study aimed to investigate the role of PRX and COPOX genes in algaenan biosynthesis.

svg.text: Figure 1: CRISPR-Cas9 targeting of PRX and COPOX genes in N. oceanica
